  2. If not:

  • Switching between SQL Standard and SQLScript

return

    select
        "id",
        "name"
    from "customers"

entry.title: SAP TM Report /SCMTMS/TOR_CORR_ITEM_RES_CHK - Resource Relevant for Time Check
entry.content:
Introduction

Resource time check relevancy issues in SAP Transportation Management (TM) can significantly impact operational efficiency and system performance. Two critical OSS notes - 3194872 and 3207567 - address fundamental problems with how the system handles resource time checks for executed documents and status changes. These corrections are essential for organizations using SAP TM to manage transportation resources effectively, particularly those experiencing Transportation Cockpit performance issues or incorrect resource conflict errors. This blog post targets SAP TM administrators, basis consultants, and functional consultants responsible for transportation management implementations.

 

OSS Notes Overview

Note 3194872: Incorrect resource time check relevancy of Executed Documents

Release Information:

  • SAP Transportation Management (TM)
  • Component: /SCMTMS/D_TORITE table
  • Severity level: High - impacts resource allocation and system performance

Problem Description: The system incorrectly maintains resource time check relevancy for documents with execution status 'Executed'. When a single vehicle resource is assigned to an executed Freight Document, the system continues to treat it as relevant for resource time checks. This causes false positive error messages stating "Resource &1 is already used by &2 within this time frame" when attempting to assign the same resource to another Freight Document, preventing document saves or setting unnecessary execution blocks.

Business Impact:

  • Operational delays due to incorrect resource conflict errors
  • Inability to properly reuse resources after execution completion
  • Increased manual intervention required for resource management
  • Reduced system efficiency and user productivity

Note 3207567: Incorrect resource time check relevancy after status changes

Release Information:

  • SAP Transportation Management (TM)
  • Component: Transportation document lifecycle management
  • Severity level: High - affects document status transitions

Problem Description: When Freight Documents transition from 'Completed' or 'Executed' status back to 'In Process' or 'In Execution', the resource time check relevancy incorrectly remains set to 'Completed' instead of reverting to 'Relevant'. This creates inconsistencies in resource availability checks and can lead to improper resource allocation decisions.

Business Impact:

  • Inconsistent resource availability calculations
  • Potential overallocation or under-utilization of resources
  • Incorrect planning decisions based on faulty resource status
  • Transportation Cockpit performance degradation with large document volumes

Root Cause Analysis

Technical Background: The core issue stems from improper handling of the RES_TIME_CHECK_REL field in table /SCMTMS/D_TORITE for AVR (Arrival) and PVR (Departure) items. The system fails to correctly update this field when document statuses change, leading to persistent resource time check relevancy even after execution completion. This particularly impacts the Transportation Cockpit's class *TOR_A_CHECK, which experiences significant runtime slowdowns when processing more than 500 documents with incorrect time check settings.

Common Scenarios:

  • High-volume transportation operations with frequent resource reuse
  • Documents undergoing multiple status transitions during their lifecycle
  • Transportation Cockpit usage with large document datasets
  • Automated resource allocation processes that depend on accurate status information

Solution Implementation

Pre-Implementation Checklist

  • Create complete system backup before applying corrections
  • Schedule maintenance window for correction instruction implementation
  • Notify users of potential temporary system unavailability
  • Identify all affected transportation documents for correction
  • Prepare rollback plan in case of implementation issues

Step-by-Step Implementation

  1. Apply Correction Instructions
    • Download and implement attached correction instructions for both notes
    • Alternatively, apply for the corresponding Support Packages if available
    • Verify successful implementation through system logs
    • Restart relevant application servers if required
  2. Execute Correction Report
    • Run report /SCMTMS/TOR_CORR_ITEM_RES_CHK to correct existing documents
    • For Note 3194872: Use parameters P_SIM (simulation mode) and P_LOG (show documents) for initial testing
    • For Note 3207567: Configure additional parameters:
      • P_COMPL: Set time check to Completed for executed documents
      • P_RELEV: Set time check to Relevant for documents in execution/process
    • Execute in production mode after successful simulation

Validation and Testing

Test Scenarios:

  • Scenario 1: Assign a resource to an executed Freight Document, then attempt to assign the same resource to a new document - should succeed without error messages
  • Scenario 2: Change document status from Executed back to In Process - resource time check relevancy should automatically update too Relevant
  • Scenario 3: Load more than 500 documents in Transportation Cockpit - performance should be improved with corrected time check settings

Success Criteria:

  • Elimination of false positive resource conflict errors
  • Proper resource time check relevancy updates during status transitions
  • Improved Transportation Cockpit performance with large document volumes
  • Successful resource reuse after document execution completion

Business Impact

Before Implementation

  • Frequent false resource conflict errors disrupting operations
  • Manual workarounds required for resource allocation
  • Transportation Cockpit performance issues with large datasets
  • Inconsistent resource availability information affecting planning

After Implementation

  • Streamlined resource allocation without false conflicts
  • Automatic and accurate resource time check relevancy updates
  • Enhanced Transportation Cockpit performance and user experience
  • Reliable resource availability data for improved planning decisions

Best Practices and Recommendations

Implementation Tips:

  • Always test corrections in development environment first
  • Execute the correction report during low-activity periods
  • Monitor system performance before and after implementation
  • Document all parameter settings used for future reference

Ongoing Maintenance:

  • Regularly monitor Transportation Cockpit performance metrics
  • Schedule periodic execution of correction reports for data quality
  • Include these corrections in future system upgrade planning
  • Establish monitoring for resource time check relevancy accuracy

Related Resources

Additional OSS Notes:

  • 3168764: Message display issues after save operations
  • 3408674: Resource check errors with identical timeframes
  • 3337830: Resource status change validation enhancements

Documentation Links:

  • SAP Transportation Management Help Portal
  • Transportation Cockpit performance optimization guides
  • Resource management configuration documentation

Conclusion

Implementing OSS notes 3194872 and 3207567 is crucial for maintaining optimal SAP TM performance and ensuring accurate resource management. These corrections eliminate critical issues that can significantly impact daily transportation operations and system efficiency. Organizations should prioritize implementing these corrections, especially those experiencing Transportation Cockpit performance issues or resource allocation conflicts. The provided correction report /SCMTMS/TOR_CORR_ITEM_RES_CHK offers a comprehensive solution for addressing both existing and future document issues.

 Refer:

3194872 Incorrect resource time check relevancy of Executed Documents

 3207567 Incorrect resource time check relevancy after status changes

Hope that can help you.

Thanks, and regards

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Discover and Publish Advanced Event Mesh Events and APIs in SAP Developer Hub
entry.content:
In today’s digital economy, event-driven architectures (EDA) enable real-time insights and seamless integration across diverse system landscapes—whether connecting SAP applications or extending integration to third-party solutions. Organizations can now more efficiently discover, publish, and consume events and APIs, empowering both developers and integration architects.

In this blog, we’ll explore what these capabilities mean in practice, how to connect Advanced Event Mesh with Developer Hub, and how to publish events from business systems into a centralized discovery catalog—bringing event-driven integration patterns into the mainstream of enterprise integration design.

Create a Destination to Connect Advanced Event Mesh with SAP Developer Hub

To enable the discovery and publication of events from Advanced Event Mesh in Developer Hub, the first step is to establish a secure connection between the two services. This connection is configured using a destination in SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

In the following sections, we’ll explain the purpose of this destination and walk through the key configuration details required to set it up successfully.

Why is a Destination Required?

A destination serves as the secure connectivity bridge between Developer Hub and your Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) instance. This connection is essential for Developer Hub to discover EventAPIs within AEM and display them as Events in the central catalog.

Note: In the current release, the destination is used exclusively for the discovery phase of the event lifecycle.

Create the Destination in SAP BTP

1. To create the destination, log in to SAP BTP Cockpit and navigate to the source subaccount where Developer Hub is enabled.

2. From the left navigation pane, go to Connectivity → Destinations and choose Create. Select From Scratch to manually define a new destination.

3. In the Destination Details section, enter all required information:

  • Name: Provide a unique and meaningful name for the destination.
  • Type: Choose HTTP as the destination type.
  • Description: Provide a brief description of the Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) system. This description appears for the AEM business system in Developer Hub.
  • URL: Enter the base URL of your Advanced Event Mesh portal.           
  • For authentication, choose BasicAuthentication.
               Username: Enter the username of the technical user. This can be an email address.
               Password: Use an API token generated from the Advanced Event Mesh portal as the password.
  • When creating the API token, ensure that the following permissions are assigned: a. Read any Application Domain (application_domain:get:*) b. Do anything to any Event API (event_api:*:*) c. Access to Event Portal Designer (event_designer:access). These permissions allow Developer Hub to read event definitions and interact with the Event portal.
  • Enter the Additional Settings: Choose Internet as the Proxy Type.
  • Add the following custom property to enable Advanced Event Mesh support in Developer Hub:  Key: sap.isuite.dh.aem.enabled Value: true              

4. Validate the destination.

After entering all details, choose Create.
You can optionally use Check Connection to verify that the destination has been configured correctly, and that Developer Hub can successfully connect to Advanced Event Mesh.

What’s Next?

Once the destination is set up, Developer Hub can start discovering events from Advanced Event Mesh. These events can then be reviewed, published, and made available to developers through the central catalog.

This simple setup step lays the foundation for enabling event-driven integration using SAP Integration Suite.

Discover and Publish Events from Advanced Event Mesh on Developer Hub

Once the destination between Advanced Event Mesh and SAP Developer Hub is in place, you can start making events available to developers by discovering and publishing them in Developer Hub.

This step is typically performed by a content administrator, who curates events and organizes them into products for easy discovery and reuse.

Before You Begin

To discover and publish events, make sure the following prerequisites are met:

  • You are assigned the AuthGroup.Content.Admin role collection.
  • EventAPIs are marked as shared in the Advanced Event Mesh portal.

Only shared events can be added to products and published in Developer Hub. If an event is not shared, update its settings in the Advanced Event Mesh portal before proceeding.

Discover Events in Developer Hub

  1. Log on to Developer Hub and navigate to Admin Center → Manage → Content. Here, you’ll see a list of available business systems. Select the Advanced Event Mesh business system to discover events exposed from it.
  2. Events in Advanced Event Mesh are organized under application domains. When you select an application domain, all events associated with that domain are displayed.
  3. If required, you can enable the option to Show shared events from other domains. This allows you to view and reuse events that have been shared across application domains.

Understand Event Visibility

Each application domain contains its own set of events:

  • Shared events are visible across all application domains.
  • Non-shared events are visible only within their own domain.

Only shared events can be added to a product in Developer Hub. This ensures that events intended for broader consumption are clearly identified and reusable.

  1. After selecting the relevant events, you can group them into a product. Products help organize events logically and make them easier for developers to discover.
  2. When creating a product, you can include:
  • Shared events from the current application domain
  • Shared events from other application domains

       This flexibility allows you to design products that align with business capabilities rather than technical boundaries.

3. Publish the product

           Once the product details are reviewed, you can choose how to proceed:

  • Save as Draft
    Keeps the product in a draft state. Draft products are not visible in the catalog and can be published later.
  • Publish
    Makes the product visible in the Developer Hub catalog so developers can discover it.
    Published products are discoverable but not yet available for subscription.

 

What Happens Next?

After publishing, your events are visible in Developer Hub and ready to be explored by developers. This enables teams to quickly understand available event streams and build event-driven applications or integrations using Advanced Event Mesh.

Together with the destination setup, this completes the core flow for exposing Advanced Event Mesh events through Developer Hub.

This approach helps organizations promote event reuse, improve discoverability, and simplify adoption of event-driven integration patterns across the landscape. 

Final Thoughts

SAP Integration Suite’s Advanced Event Mesh paired with Developer Hub empowers organizations to treat events as first-class citizens in integration landscapes.

By connecting Advanced Event Mesh to Developer Hub and publishing your event sources and APIs, you:

  • Promote transparency of event streams
  • Enable faster development cycles
  • Support modern application patterns that rely on real-time business context

Whether you’re driving integrations for ERP, CRM, third-party SaaS systems, or custom applications, this capability helps you move from point-to-point communication to a flexible, scalable event-driven architecture.

Hey Anna,

The short answer is that the SQL editor is very - ehm - simple (but I'm sure it has a great personality).
The Editor will try to derive the columns from whatever it finds immediately after the "Return" statement. 
It will put no effort into it, and any logic between the output and the source will break it. 

An example:

Any kind of obfuscation between the editor and the source tables will result in the editor throwing it's hands in the air. 

Here is a really basic example with a simple temp table between the source and the output:

Even this simple script confuses the poor things. 
It does derive the columns, but everything is cast as a string(100).

Adding a new "Ranking" column, which is clearly an integer, will still result in a string(100).

A workaround (not really).

If you already have an object with the structure you want; one thing that makes it less-awful, it to add a 

return select * from source

And validate. That will generate the structure and derive the schema correctly. 

You can then write your script on top, and replace the "Return" statement later.
This is shaky at best, but it's the least awful way I found.

entry.title: Re: Settlement periods & Billing Date period of service c...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, Billing plan = schedule of billing dates and amounts. It doesn’t change the contract item quantity. Order quantity = the contractual unit (e.g., 1 month). When the invoice request is created, the system copies the item quantity from the contract, not from the billing plan period.

Options to achieve “6 months” on the invoice

Adjust the contract item quantity
Instead of “1 month,” set the item quantity to “6 months” if the billing plan is half‑yearly. The billing plan will then align with the quantity shown on the invoice.

Use Periodic Billing Plans
In the billing plan, you can define the billing rule (e.g., “periodic billing”). This allows the system to accumulate the billing quantity according to the settlement period (monthly, quarterly, half‑yearly). With proper customizing, the invoice can reflect the total period quantity.

Custom Logic (BAdI)
If you want the system to automatically adjust the billed quantity based on the billing plan period, you can implement a BAdI for billing plan processing. This enhancement can calculate the correct quantity (e.g., 6 months) before the invoice request is created.

entry.title: Violent Geometry of Gold: from Flatlandia to Spacelandia
entry.content:
Let us talk gold.  And Newmont Corp:

Newmont Corporation (stock ticker NEM) is the world’s largest gold miner.  And one of the top SAP customers.  Same is true for Barrick Mining (B), its competitor and – in certain areas – a partner.  For example, Barrick-Newmont JV in Nevada is the world’s largest gold complex.  Barrick is also an SAP customer.

Just to put things in perspective, here is the heat map of the EV for the various players in metals and mining:

 

WHY GOLD RETURNS?  AND PAIRING GOLD-STOCK RETURNS

Recent gold's ascension to unprecedented value prompted many to examine its return dynamics and correlations with various other returns.  We are decided to follow suit.

First, we define returns: stock price changes in NEM and B vs price changes in gold.  Specifically, the raw price data allows us to create time series of returns: first for Newmont Corporation’s stock and the second for gold.  In both cases, monthly returns are defined as

 

 

 

Dataset: we took 1985-2025 (40 years) gold prices from the World Gold Council (gold.org) and Newmont stock prices (NEM) from Yahoo Finance, turning both into returns.  The resulting data contains 490 monthly returns.

And most recent ones:

Let us zoom in on the first pair of returns: 1985 February saw NEM stock price decline by 0.037 and gold decline by 0.011, i.e., the two monthly returns were -0.011 and -0.037 respectively.

Pairing these returns essentially answers the following question: “Given gold moved by this amount in month t, how did Newmont move in the same month?”

  • Statistics call this a bivariate observation (or observation from a joint distribution)
  • Finance calls this a paired return realization (or joint asset-factor return where gold is a factor)
  • Mathematically, such paired return is point or vector in, i.e., in two-dimensional space. We will prefer the vector nomenclature here.

With the vector of returns definition in mind, we have the following for February 1985:

 

 

Plotting all such paired returns produces the following scatterplot:

 

As we established, each dot is a vector of returns.  Visually and intuitively, the vector is an arrow starting at the origin [0,0] and extending to such observation coordinates

as shown on the plot below:

 

Put plainly, in February of 1985, both assets - gold and NEM – were down, i.e., produced negative returns.  This is why the vector resides in the 3rd quadrant.

What is the magnitude, i.e., length of this vector?

This vector magnitude conveys the length of that month’s movement, i.e., how large the combined movement was across both gold and Newmont in February 1985.  How “violent” the month was.

Close up on this vector allows us to see it in greater detail:

 

Specifically, we can visualize the movement: Newmont moved much more down than gold moved left.  This specifically means: both moves into the “negative territory” but Newmont moved much more. 

We estimate the angle in two ways.

  1. Recalling SOHCAHTOA,

            Since we start from the origin and go counter clock-wise to the red vector, the angle is

 

Put another way, measuring θ from the positive x-axis, we have tan(θ) = y / x, which captures relative sensitivity of NEM to gold for that month (for that realization only).  This is local sensitivity, not structural beta (yet).

We use -180 degrees to match the polar coordinates. 

  1. Alternatively, using atan2(y, x), the angle naturally places the vector in Quadrant III, confirming a joint negative regime.

Our economic interpretation is simple: the move happened in quadrant III, i.e., negative economic regime (decline for both) and we know that NEM realized over 3x of the gold negative return.

We contrast February 1985 with March, where both Newmont stock and gold went up producing positive returns:

 

Here, the gold went up 2x of NEM. In other words, gold rallied strongly, NEM participated but more conservatively. Therefore,

Angle of 45 degrees would indicate equal movement, but our angle here is only 27.5 degrees which again indicates x-dominated change as opposed to the y-dominated one.  That month, gold won.

In relative magnitude terms.

But what is important for our inference about the relationship is how much gold’s movement that month “showed up” in NEM’s return?  Answer: approximately 50%.  This is where the interpretation becomes interesting since we observe realization of sensitivity.  We are not estimating NEM’s beta yet; but are observing the sensitivity – via vectors.  In other words, we already see some asymmetry: when gold moved down in February, NEM moved down 3x.  When next month gold moved up, NEM moved 0.5x.

So, we can reformulate our findings so far in this way:

We can start generalizing now.

 

HOW MUCH OF NEM’s MOVEMENT IS EXPLAINED BY GOLD MOVEMENT? 

This question can be reformulated in “vector terms”: what is the projection of the joint NEM/gold return vector onto the gold direction?

In this particular situation, the case is trivial because the gold resides on x axis and the coordinate 0.073 easily depicts such projection.  However, we want to generalize this rule for the more complicated cases where the factor (e.g., gold) direction vector is not easily located on x-axis.  The projection

Since we asked the question how much the joint movement is gold-aligned, we ought to investigate the other part as well:

 

WHAT HAPPENS TO THE PART WHICH IS NOT GOLD-ALIGNED? 

Financially, this question centers on non-gold, i.e., NEM-idiosyncratic returns (movements in price).  These movements are uncorrelated with the gold movements.  Well, “uncorrelated” applies to the entire data set, so for one month, the lack of relationship here is better explained as orthogonal to the gold direction by construction (uncorrelated only in aggregate).  We define orthogonality month by month; we discover correlation across the entire period.

Let us again use March 1985 since we are familiar with this month’s returns.  Mathematically, we express the “gold unrelated” NEM movement (return) as orthogonal vector.  In plain English, this is the “leftover” which has zero alignment with gold:

In vector form, this orthogonal vector (perpendicular to the gold projection) is

i.e., difference between two vectors: joint movement vector – its projection onto gold.  Why is this vector perpendicular to the “gold vector”?  Because we made gold our explanatory variable.  If we were to use the typical regression language, gold return[s] is the independent (predictor) variables while NEM’s return[s] is the dependent (predicted) variable.  Clearly, the relationship in reality may be bi-directional and more nuanced, but for now we made “an executive decision”, so to speak: treat gold as the explanatory and NEM as the explained variable (x and y respectively).  This is why the orthogonal vector (blue arrow) is perpendicular to the “gold vector.”

 

Financially,

  • the dotted line vector along the x axis (the “gold vector”) says, “What did NEM return because of the gold movement this month?” (assuming linearity, not causality, and no stability over time)
  • while the vertical blue vector says, “What did NEM return that cannot be explained by gold this month?”

Given this distinction, we can treat the orthogonal (blue) vector as a residual: it provides the gold-unexplained return on the NEM stock. In other words, the projection of the joint vector onto gold represents the gold-explained component of NEM, while the blue vector depicts the gold-unexplained portion of the NEM return.

We can see that the residual vectors reside in the direction perpendicular to gold.  We do not see any systematic tilt left: the cloud of the returns is centered on y=0 and appears symmetric.  In other words, we observe typical orthogonality in

This means that when gold moves by 1 unit, NEM moves by 0.075 units.  In other words, +1% gold month corresponds, on average, to +0.075% month for NEM price change. NB! this beta reflects monthly decimal returns and should not be compared directly to conventional annualized betas.

 

Residual:

 

 

 

 

Beta of gold is the systematic gold-driven component of NEM (linear approximation).  This is important for the decision to hedge, increase or decrease gold exposure (via NEM stock), and alleviate macroeconomic shocks.

 

The residual is everything else specific to NEM: mine issues, management decisions and execution, even market noise (equity moves unrelated to gold).

In sum: this plot shows that once we remove the gold-aligned component of NEM’s returns, what remains is geometrically orthogonal, statistically uncorrelated, and economically idiosyncratic.

 

MANY VECTORS: WHICH ONE BEST DESCRIBES THEM ALL?

 

 

As we established earlier, dot product of two vectors measures how much one vector moves along the other, like joint vector movement along gold we described earlier.  Given we have many joint returns (490 precisely), i.e., vectors v1, v2, …, vn (depicted in different colors above), how can we find a single direction vector u such that vectors have large projections onto u?  Let us define “large” first.

If we sum just the projections, some resulting scalars will have negative sign and some positive, so some positive and negative months would cancel.  We would get “net drift” but this is a different story.  So, what do we do?

Like we do in estimate variance, we square the projections:

Therefore, we are looking for the unit vector u which maximizes such sum of squares, or “squared projection”:

 

With the NEM/Gold example, this algorithm chooses a joint Gold–NEM movement direction that explains as much total magnitude of monthly co-movement as possible, regardless of the sign.

Here is the resulting projection.  Given the maximization of the “squared projection” algorithm above, this line has the following meaning: when we orthogonally project all monthly vectors onto this line, the total squared length of those projections is maximized.

 

 

·     Line is almost vertical, which means that NEM returns dominate

·     This is a line, meaning direction +/-u are equivalent: bulls and crashes equally matter

·     Interestingly, our data is clustered around the x axis and is horizontally distributed… but clustering near the x-axis means large directional alignment with the x-axis, but not necessarily large magnitude-weighted projections: even modest-angle but high-magnitude vertical component yt dominates the squared length (magnitude is quadratic).

In other words, many small calm months near horizontal “yield to” fewer crisis / equity-shock months with large vertical magnitude.

·     Gold moves often, but modestly

·     NEM moves less often, but violently

·     Our algorithm rewards violent months quadratically, i.e., though high energy of such months

These findings may feel counter-intuitive at first, therefore we ought to explore it with the vector magnitudes in mind.

We recall that each joint movement vector (paired return vector which we started with) has the following length, or magnitude:

But we remember that our maximization algorithm squares such vector:

In plain English – perhaps not entire correctly but intuitively – vector length is the hypothenuse.  Its projection (the adjacent side) is hypothenuse multiplied by cos(angle) – this comes from the Pythagorean identity.  But the maximization algorithm, squares such projection (the dot product of v and u above).  The hypotenuse measures how large each vector is but contains no information about orientation, so it cannot distinguish between directions; projections introduce directional dependence, and squaring them yields a rotation-sensitive, non-canceling measure of how much joint movement lies along a candidate direction.

 

Panel 1 on the top plots each vector (i.e., joint movement as a vector from the origin). Most months live in a tight band near zero, but a few months spike dramatically (1987, 1998, 2008, 2015, 2020).

Pane 2 in the middle conveys the energy. Since monthly returns are max 0.77 for NEM and 0.18 for gold, squaring them makes them smaller. But the relative importance of such violent months rises.

Panel 3 conveys that clearly: out of 490 months (40 years of data), just 12 (!) have over a quarter of energy.

Our geometric findings map to the financial interpretation:

  • Most months: small, noisy co-movement between gold and NEM
  • Rare months: systemic stress or regime shifts
    • 1987 crash
    • 1998 LTCM / Russia default
    • 2008 GFC
    • 2020 COVID
  • Those months define the economic meaning of “joint movement”

What surprises me here: though most months cluster near the horizontal axis, a few high-energy months dominate the squared-projection algorithm; consequently, the optimal direction aligns with those violent joint movements rather than with the calm majority.

So, we might have proven that violent / high energy months translate into the near vertical orientation of the optimized line, the line that represents single direction of all 490 vectors.  What does it mean?  It does not mean that gold returns are irrelevant or NEM returns are completely independent.  Rather, we can conclude that the dominant joint-movement direction in 1985-2025 is driven by NEM’s variability, not by gold’s average alignment.

The economically meaningful joint shocks between gold and Newmont are equity-driven, not metal-price-driven.

 

CROSS-PRODUCT: WHAT CAN IT TELL US ABOUT NEM AND GOLD?

Their cross product is defined as

 

We can see this cross product as the 3rd axis vector sticking up, i.e., perpendicular to the plane of the two original vectors. Small red vector here:

 

 

This red upward looking vector is small because we multiply numbers which are each below |1|.  Interestingly, the magnitude of this vector represents the area of the parallelogram formed by the two original vectors,

I find it amazing that this barely visible “z-axis” orthogonal vector – the cross product of our two Feb and March vectors – is indeed the area of the parallelogram formed by the two vectors.

What does the cross-product vector – or the parallelogram area – mean for NEM and gold?  The magnitude of the orthogonal vector (or area of the parallelogram) represents the joint “volatility” volume, or the degree of uncorrelated movement between gold and NEM.  Well, more correctly, the area measures directional misalignment x magnitude across two realizations.

The larger the area of such parallelogram (or the height of the orthogonal vector), the more NEM and gold moved freely independently, and the smaller the area, the more they acted “in sync”.  If gold and NEM were perfectly “correlated” (this is not correlation yet – which requires many observations) during these two months, the parallelogram would collapse into a single line and the orthogonal vector would be zero in length.  Therefore, in such a scenario, a portfolio of two assets – NEM and gold – would offer no diversification benefit for those realizations.

On the other hand, ideal diversification scenario for these two realizations would be the maximum parallelogram area, where

and the orthogonal vector is maximal in length (magnitude).

 

As a recap for our two asset / two vector situation:

  • Two joint-return vectors (Month 1 and Month 2) form a parallelogram
  • Its area equals the magnitude of the cross product
  • Zero area ⇔ perfect directional alignment
  • Area measures directional change + scale (not correlation in statistics)

Now we can ask ourselves about multiple month pairs within the entire 1985-2025 time horizon: what may the cross product of such pairs tell us? 

 

There is no cross product of the entire period, but we can calculate multiple cross products of month pairs and plot the distribution of such parallelogram areas (aka cross product orthogonal vectors).

 

As a reminder: the smaller the area, the more in sync gold and NEM moved (more colinear) and the larger the area, the more different the returns were: regime break (exogenous events perhaps) and strong directional disagreement / magnitude mismatch.

 

 

 

Rolling 2 adjacent months, i.e., 489 2-month pairs (t, t+1)

All possible month pairs, i.e., 119,805 pairs

How do co-movements (joint returns) for gold and NEM change month to month?

Global cloud geometry

 

 

We see how right skewed data is. Again, many calm months witness relatively “synchronized” movements of gold and NEM returns (left handside).  But there are “violent” months where returns are very “uncoordinated” both in direction (angular disagreement) and magnitude.  In sum, the right handside area of this boxplot represent macroeconomic events and market stress.

This full-pair geometry reinforces the same idea, just with many more pairs.

Calm months dominate in count, violent months dominate in impact. 

Consistent with our earlier findings.

 

 

3D “SPACELANDIA” WITH A 3RD ASSET: WHAT CAN WE LEARN?

First, let us add another company: Barrick Mining.

With this addition, our raw data of returns has one more column:

 

Let us now visualize the 3D space of December 2025:

 

 

 

Here i, j, k denote the standard unit vectors along the Gold (x-), NEM (y-), and Barrick (z-) axes, respectively.

 

 

This single 3D joint-movement vector represents one realization (joint movement returns) in Gold–NEM–Barrick space.
To examine diversification and independence across the three assets, we zoom in on how such vectors span three-dimensional space across time.

While in Flatlandia (2D) the cross product of two vectors - two joint return vectors for Gold and NEM – produced the area of parallelogram (how coordinated or uncoordinated return moves), in Spacelandia (3D), the triple scalar product of three vectors produces the volume of a parallelepiped:

 

 

Thus, this means that now we are looking at three months, e.g., December, November, and October 2025.

In other words,

 

and so on.

 

What does the formula mean geometrically?

What does “big vs small volume” mean financially?  How many independent directions did the system move across those 3 months.

  • Volume ≈ 0: the 3 monthly joint-movement vectors are nearly coplanar / linearly dependent.
    Across these three months, the Gold–NEM–Barrick system mostly moved in one common pattern; nothing ‘new’ happened in the 3-asset relationship.
  • Large volume: the three months span a genuinely 3D chunk of space.
    Across these three months, the relationship among Gold, NEM, and Barrick produced a new linearly independent shock pattern—these assets did not just scale up/down together; their co-movement structure shifted.

Like we did in the Flatlandia with the cross products across the entire time period (490 months – 1 because of rolling adjacent 2-month convention), for Spacelandia, we can perform the same for the rolling adjacent 3 month parallelepiped volumes:

 

 

We observe somewhat similar picture: there are a lot of calm months where the volume of the RD parallelepiped is small (joint return movements appear synchronized in direction and magnitude) and there are “violent” months where such joint return movements are misaligned in direction and magnitude (volume of the resulting parallelepiped is high).

 

Finance Color #1: It clicked: diversification is episodic, not average

Our geometry shows that diversification between gold and mining equities (NEM and B) is state-dependent, not constant:

  • Most months: small areas / volumes → assets behave as if driven by a common macro regime
  • Rare months: large areas / volumes → diversification suddenly becomes real

Therefore,

  • long-run correlations look “moderate”
  • but portfolio protection often shows up only during stress

In other words, this geometry captures when diversification matters, not just whether it exists on average.

Finance Color #2: Volumes identify regime transitions, not just volatility

This is the “value add” by geometry:

  • Large magnitudes = volatility
  • Large areas = change in pairwise structure
  • Large volumes = change in system structure

So, a large rolling 3-month volume is not “just a volatile period” — it is a period in which the relationship among Gold, Newmont, and Barrick itself changed.  Financial models break down, hedging become unstable, new factors emerge and/or replace previous ones.

As an extra step, I re-examined the history of various events “surrounding” such extreme returns on the right handside.  Picking just a few of those located on the most far end of the x-axis, yields the following picture and details below:

Rare large-volume rolling 3-month windows (chronological)

1986-04 → 1986-06

  • Macro / markets: Post-Volcker disinflation environment (CPI in us at 10-14% so Feds increased the rate beyond 20%); USD strength and falling inflation expectations.
  • Gold: Weak and unstable price action as real rates rose.
  • Miners: Equity-specific adjustments amplified moves relative to gold.
  • Why volume spikes: Gold and miners responded differently to shifting rate expectations, breaking the usual “gold proxy” behavior.

1987-08 → 1987-10

  • Macro / markets: Lead-up to and aftermath of the October 1987 stock market crash (on Oct 19, 1987 Dow Jones lost 22%).
  • Gold: Initially mixed, then benefited as a crisis hedge.
  • Miners: Extreme equity volatility dominated fundamentals.
  • Why volume spikes: Equity shock introduced a new independent direction orthogonal to gold’s behavior.  Liquidity “evaporated” so the correlation is almost 1.

1998-08 → 1998-10

  • Macro / markets: Russian default (domestic debt and subsequent ruble devaluation) + Long-Term Capital Management crisis (ironically, LTCM, a hedge fund, was founded by Nobel Prize laureates in Economics including Robert Merton and Myron Scholes); severe global risk aversion.
  • Gold: Safe-haven demand surged after prolonged weakness.
  • Miners: Sharp equity dislocations due to leverage and funding stress.
  • Why volume spikes: Breakdown of historical gold–miner co-movement during systemic stress.

1999-09 → 1999-11

  • Macro / markets: Late-cycle equity exuberance (NASDAQ is in vertical ascent) approaching dot-com peak.  Traditional valuations? Dismissed.
  • Gold: Structural weakness, including sales (not purchases!) by Central banks.
  • Miners: Equity market forces overwhelmed commodity linkage.  They traded like ordinary stocks rather than gold-linked assets.
  • Why volume spikes: Miners decouple from gold amid speculative equity flows.

2008-09 → 2008-11/12 → 2009-02

  • Macro / markets: Systemic collapse after Lehman, followed by rapid stabilization via extraordinary monetary intervention.
  • Gold: Immediate safe-haven surge during panic, then sustained strength as QE and monetary debasement expectations formed.
  • Miners: Initial collapse with equities despite rising gold, followed by a violent rebound once equity markets stabilized.
  • Why volume spikes: Two-phase regime shift — first forced deleveraging overrides gold linkage, then re-alignment as the system transitions into a new equilibrium.

2016-01 → 2016-03 — Global growth scare → commodity & gold rebound

  • Macro / markets: Early-2016 global risk-off driven by an oil collapse (oil drops to some $26/barrel – lowest in a decade), China growth fears, and recession concerns; sentiment stabilized by March.  Feds: in late 2015 raise rates to 0.5% first time since 2006 (akin to “emergency policy is about to end”)
  • Gold: Strong rally as investors sought safety and repriced lower real rates.
  • Miners: Sharp rebound as gold surged and balance-sheet fears eased.  Both NEM and B enter 2016 deeply out of favor. Had spent years cutting costs, selling assets, and repairing balance sheets.
  • Why volume spikes: Sudden regime shift — from deflation panic to reflation relief — forced rapid repositioning in gold and mining equities.

These simple bullet points provide just some color to how high can the volumes go.  As a reminder: the volumes here (triple scalar product) represent how different the returns were.  Large volumes - the outliers we discuss – indicate situations where gold returns continued but NEM and B returns changed drastically; key is that these returns moved differently relative to each other.

 

RECAP: GEOMETRY = FRIEND OR FOE?

In this note we examined the relationship between gold and Newmont returns through a geometric lens, gradually expanding the dimensionality of analysis.  Then we added Barrick returns and therefore examined even more nuanced interplay of gold and equities as well as time (regimes such as calm months vs. economic and market stress).

First came monthly gold–Newmont returns as joint movement vectors in two-dimensional space.  Vector projections allowed decomposing each month’s movement into a gold-aligned component and an orthogonal component.  This orthogonal residual is geometrically perpendicular to the gold direction by construction, statistically uncorrelated in aggregate, and economically interpretable as NEM-specific behavior (e.g., disposition of a mine, acquisition, or any other NEM-specific and gold-agnostic corporate and market factor).  This construction reveals the geometric foundation of linear regression without invoking probabilistic assumptions.

Moving beyond individual months: many joint-return vectors simultaneously allow – via the maximized squared projections direction - showing that a small number of high-energy months dominate the long-run joint behavior of gold and Newmont (joint return-wise).  Calm months are numerous but economically secondary; crisis periods define the dominant co-movement structure.

The cross product starts bridging Flatlandia to Spacelandia allowing to examine how joint return behavior changes across time. The area of the parallelogram formed by two monthly joint-movement vectors - or the resulting orthogonal vector magnitude - captures directional misalignment and scale across realizations.  Rolling and global distributions of these areas reveal a strongly right-skewed structure: most months are synchronized, while rare episodes reflect regime breaks and stress.  Calm months dominate in count; violent months dominate in impact.  In a sense, the newly formed “z-axis” cross-product confirms the findings of the [purely 2D] squared projections.

Adding Barrick Mining price moves turns this into the 3D “Gold–Newmont–Barrick space.”  Here, diversification and independence are no longer captured by areas but by volumes, measured via the scalar triple product of three joint-movement vectors.  Rolling three-month volumes quantify whether the system behaves as effectively two-dimensional or explores genuinely three-dimensional dynamics.  Periods of large volume correspond to shifts in the joint structure of returns rather than simple increases in volatility.  Our findings here are consistent with those above (projections and cross-products):

The economic meaning of gold–mining equity (NEM an B) relationships is defined not by average behavior, but by rare, high-energy episodes in which co-movement geometry changes.  Vector geometry provides a unified language to describe projection, residuals, regime shifts, and diversification in a way that is intuitive, rigorous, and directly interpretable for financial decision-making.

Perhaps this picture for the 24 years of the market from Visual Capitalist (link) provides an independent validation for our findings:

 

 

ANOTHER RECAP: “SO WHAT” REGARDING THE VECTORS AS ANALYTICAL TOOLS?

Throughout the analysis, it was becoming clearer to me that, on one hand, findings from the previous layer of complexity – e.g., projections and simple orthogonal vector – repeated with the next level of complexity.  So, the question becomes, ‘Why go to another level of complexity then?”  On the other hand, certain additional insights emerge with the growing complexity and increasing dimensionality of the analyses (from ‘Flatlandia’ to ‘Spacelandia’).

This table attempts to summarize the incremental value of the growing dimensionality: from “simple 2D” to “transitional 2D” (cross product and resulting orthogonal vector) to the “full 3D”:

 

Layer / Tool

Dimensional Regime

Mathematical Object

What It Measures (Plain English)

What It Adds Beyond Previous Layer

Concrete Insight in This Note

Executive-Level “So What”

Vector Projection (starting point)

1D (within 2D space)

 

How much a month aligns with the main co-movement direction

Establishes baseline linear relationship

Most months weakly aligned; few dominate

“Most months don’t move the needle.”

Squared Projection

1D (within 2D space)

 

Energy contributed along that direction

Removes sign noise; highlights dominance

Tail months dominate total energy

“Risk contribution is extremely uneven over time.”

Orthogonal Component

2D (full plane)

 

How much of the move cannot be explained by the main relationship

Separates expected vs. unexpected behavior

Large deviations cluster in turbulent periods

“This is when the hedge breaks down.”

Cross Product (Area)

Bridge: 2D → 3D

 

Month-to-month instability in direction & magnitude

Introduces dynamics and curvature

Right-skewed: calm regimes, violent breaks

“Relationships don’t drift — they snap.”

Scalar Triple Product (Volume)

True 3D space

 

Whether movements require three independent dimensions

Tests incremental diversification

Large volumes occur only in crisis windows

“The third asset matters only under stress.”

What feels like increasing mathematical complexity may be a controlled expansion of dimensional freedom.  

  • Earlier tools deliberately restrict the analysis to one direction inside a plane: is there a dominant relationship at all?
  • Orthogonal components then allow full 2D freedom: when does that relationship fail?
  • The cross product is the bridge—while still living in 2D, it produces a vector that points out of the plane, signaling instability and curvature over time.
  • Finally, the scalar triple product moves fully into 3D, asking the hardest question: do three assets truly span independent risk space, or are they effectively planar?

I expected the higher dimensionality tools to overturn some earlier results.  But they kept confirming them.  Perhaps the fact that all layers of complexity for all assets – gold, NEM and Barrick - converge on the same story is actually a sort of validation.  Each added dimension removes a potential excuse: “it’s just linear,” “it’s just volatility,” “it’s just scale.”  Remaining is a conclusion: risk, instability, and diversification all concentrate in rare, high-stress episodes.  This is the insight from 40 years of gold, NEM and B returns.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Facebook login via mobile browser
entry.content:
There is a known issue with Facebook login in the popup.  It happens because Facebook has started adding new security headers that block pop-ups from being communicated from cross-origin parent windows, which eventually prevents popups from closing and notify parent windows that a session was created.

Note:  These headers are not present all the time or not on all Facebook URLs, so the issue does not always reproduce.

Solution:

Make sure to implement social login with the authFlow: "redirect" parameter that can be invoked through either:

  • the global WebSDK Configuration,
  • the accounts.showScreenSet JS WebSDK method,
  • or the accounts.socialLogin JS Web SDK method

depending on what aligns best with your current implementation.

The default flow - authFlow: "popup" - does not work well in mobile browser environments due to different handling of cookies, iFrames, etc. that our Web SDK depends on. CNAME and Custom API Domain setup is required when using authFlow: "redirect".
